A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

Computed tomography (CT) is a method for imaging and analysing features in rock, mineral or soil specimens in three dimensions using energy attenuation of photons (X-ray tomography), neutrons (neutron tomography), ultrasonic waves (ultrasound tomography), or using magnetic resonance (magnetic resonance imaging). The detected data are used to reconstruct the internal distribution of materials.

Seismic tomography is a technique for imaging the subsurface of the Earth with seismic waves produced by controlled ‘active’ sources such as vibrations or explosions, or natural ‘passive’ sources such as earthquakes, wind, waves or human activity. P-, S-, and surface waves can be used for tomographic models of different resolutions based on seismic wavelength, wave source distance, and the seismograph array coverage. The data received at seismometers are used to solve an inverse problem, wherein the locations of reflection and refraction of the wave paths are determined. This solution can be used to create 3D images of velocity anomalies which may be interpreted as structural, thermal, or compositional variations.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The non-destructive, three-dimensional characterization of earth and planetary materials that uses material-penetrating energy sources. Tomography methods in Earth Science include experiments in controlled laboratory settings such as computed tomography of rock samples or soils, and field experiments such as seismic tomography of the Solid Earth.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.
